author: mklement0
body:
<sup>Related: #6382</sup>

Currently, `Get-Member` doesn't offer a _direct_ way to inspect a type's constructors.

The current workarounds are:

```powershell
# This gives a reasonable representation, but is obscure.
'foo'.GetType()::new
# It's easier with a type literal.
[string]::new

# This works too, but is both obscure and the resulting representation
# is single-line and therefore not that helpful.
'foo' | Get-Member -Static -MemberType Method -Name new
```

**Wishful thinking**:

```powershell
> 'foo' | Get-Member -MemberType Constructor

OverloadDefinitions                                                                                                                                                                
-------------------                                                                                                                                                                
string new(System.Char*, System.Private.CoreLib, Version=4.0.0.0, Culture=neutral, PublicKeyToken=7cec85d7bea7798e value)                                                          
string new(System.Char*, System.Private.CoreLib, Version=4.0.0.0, Culture=neutral, PublicKeyToken=7cec85d7bea7798e value, int startIndex, int length)                              
string new(System.SByte*, System.Private.CoreLib, Version=4.0.0.0, Culture=neutral, PublicKeyToken=7cec85d7bea7798e value)                                                         
string new(System.SByte*, System.Private.CoreLib, Version=4.0.0.0, Culture=neutral, PublicKeyToken=7cec85d7bea7798e value, int startIndex, int length)                             
string new(System.SByte*, System.Private.CoreLib, Version=4.0.0.0, Culture=neutral, PublicKeyToken=7cec85d7bea7798e value, int startIndex, int length, System.Text.Encoding enc)   
string new(char[] value, int startIndex, int length)                                                                                                                               
string new(char[] value)                                                                                                                                                           
string new(char c, int count)                                                                                                                                                      
```

This would require adding a `Constructor` value to enumeration type `[System.Management.Automation.PSMemberTypes]` and supporting it accordingly.

Note that both an _instance_ of a type and a _type itself_ should be supported as input (without the need for `-Static`, because constructors are implicitly and invariably _type_-level members; see also: #6382

Environment data
----------------

Written as of:

```powershell
PowerShell Core v6.0.1
```
title: Extend Get-Member to support inspecting constructors too
